user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueuePut_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_QueuePut_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *data, size_t size, uint32 flags)
{
    int32                            return_code;
    int                              result;
    struct timespec                  ts;
    OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token);

    /*
     * NOTE - using a zero timeout here for the same reason that QueueGet does ---
     * checking the attributes and doing the actual send is non-atomic, and if
     * two threads call QueuePut() at the same time on a nearly-full queue,
     * one could block.
     */
    memset(&ts, 0, sizeof(ts));

    /* send message */
    do
    {
        result = mq_timedsend(impl->id, data, size, 1, &ts);
    } while (result == -1 && errno == EINTR);

    if (result == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else if (errno == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return_code = OS_QUEUE_FULL;
    }
    else
    {
        /* Something else went wrong */
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueuePut_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t OS_impl_queue_table[OS_MAX_QUEUES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    mqd_t id;
} OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that assign to or otherwise modify any of the function parameters (token, data, size, flags). Specific reasoning:
- There are no assignments to token, data, size, or flags anywhere in the function body.
- The macro usage OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token) ultimately evaluates to &OS_impl_queue_table[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(token)]. This takes the address of the dereferenced token object but does not modify the token pointer itself.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken takes a const OS_object_token_t * and only reads token->obj_idx; it does not modify the parameter or the object.
- The data parameter is passed (read-only) to mq_timedsend, which takes a const message pointer; the pointer and its target are not modified in this function.
- size and flags are only read (no writes or updates).
- Local variables (impl, ts, result, return_code) are used and modified, which is allowed.

Therefore, no fragments require further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
